story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsEmily Blunt will step into Julie Andrews's formidable shoes as the magical nanny, set for a brand new adventureClick to followThe Independent CultureThough Disney has been methodically working through its older classics of late (in what appears to be an effort to remake its entire canon) one film has instead been given the sequel treatment.Mary Poppins&nbspReturns will add a second chapter to the 1964 film, which won five Academy Awards and starred Julie Andrews as a magical nanny who swoops in to save the dysfunctional Banks family. &nbspHere is everything we know so far about the new film.&nbspEmily Blunt as Mary Poppins: Blunt has earned a reputation as one of the UK’s finest talents, thanks to roles in A Quiet Place and The Girl on the Train, but Mary Poppins Returns may prove to be her most ambitious role yet. Stepping into Julie Andrews’s formidable shoes, Blunt has promised to deliver a new take on the character – one that still pays tribute to Andrews’s&nbspperformance, but draws more heavily from the version of Poppins we see in P.L. Travers’s source books. “She’s a little meaner,” Blunt teased.Lin-Manuel Miranda as Jack: The adult protégé of Burt (played by Dick Van Dyke in the 1964 original), is not a chimney sweep this time, but a “leerie” – a person who rides around on a bicycle&nbspwith a ladder&nbspto light the street lamps of London, then douses them in the morning.New Mary Poppins Returns trailer sees Emily Blunt singing and dancingJulie Andrews on why she won't appear in Mary Poppins ReturnsBen Whishaw as Michael: The grown-up version of Matthew Garber’s character from the 1964 film, Michael still lives in the same house on Cherry Tree Lane, and has followed in his father’s footsteps by working as a banker at the Fidelity Fiduciary Bank in London. Michael has three children, though it’s been implied his wife has recently died, putting the family in a crisis.Emily Mortimer as Jane: The grown-up version of Karen Dotrice’s character from the 1964 film, Jane has inherited her mother’s suffragette spirit, working as a union organiser.Julie Walters as Ellen: Employed as Michael’s housekeeper, Ellen will surely find herself involved in Mary’s antics.Created with Sketch.The best films of 2018 (so far) Show all 16Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.From its slow-burning beginning, s develops into an epic melodrama. It’s a wartime story in which, for a change, the men are relegated to supporting roles. It follows in a tradition of French rural family sagas like Jean De Florette or Manon Des Sources. The landscapes and the changing seasons play as much of a part in the story as the main characters.Dark River offers little such consolation. It has some lyrical and delicate moments but the mood is generally overwhelmingly bleak and lugubrious. Incest and abuse don’t leave much space for any comic interludes. This is a powerful film with a grinding intensity about it. Light relief it isn’t but Dark River still has quite an impact.Late on in Argentinean director Lucrecia Martel’s startling, highly original new feature, Zama, a character who has just had both his arms cut off, is advised to “shove your stumps in the sand … if you don’t bleed out, you’ll survive.” It’s a grisly, darkly humorous moment in a film that continually surprises us with both its brutality and its lyricism.The most dispiriting aspect of this otherwise enrapturing Oscar-nominated animated feature is that its storyline still seems so current. The film depicts an Afghan society in which women don’t have a face. It is set during the Taliban rule, which lasted from the mid-1990s until late 2001, but this doesn’t feel like a period piece. Seventeen years after the Taliban were ousted from power in Afghanistan following the US invasion, the plight of women in the country appears hardly to have improved. Spike Lee’s work sometimes risks sensory overload. He fires off so many different ideas and storytelling styles that audiences can become bamboozled by his scattergun approach. BlacKkKlansman is one of his very best films because the digressions are as entertaining as ever but don’t get in the way of the main story.Much of the pleasure in Aardman films has always lain in their gently ironic, Alan Bennett-like humour. They take very exotic characters and subject matter but then deal with them in a matter-of-fact fashion. They make a virtue out of their own relative modesty. Early Man isn’t the flashiest animated feature that you’ll see this year but it is certainly the most likeable. 716 Isle of DogsLike all of Wes Anderson’s work, Isle Of Dogs is very stylised, very offbeat and characterised by its extremely dry and often ironic humour. This Japanese-set stop-motion fable is also gorgeous to look at – packed full of intricate visual detail. It deals with some weighty themes (ethnic cleansing, fascism and corruption) but does so in an idiosyncratic fashion.816 Three Billboards Outside of Ebbing, MissouriWriter-director Martin McDonagh has a host of award-winning plays behind him but his movies haven’t always lived up to his stage work. This one certainly does. It shares some of the dark and nihilistic humour found in McDonagh’s previous film, Seven Psychopaths.In an era of wearisome poltergeist movies, haunted house stories and torture porn, A Quiet Place is a refreshingly pared-down and very original affair. Director John Krasinski relies on editing, sound effects and off-screen action to crank up the tension. We do see the creatures from time to time, sometimes even in extreme closeup. They are very grotesque, bigger versions of the polyp-like succubus which exploded out of John Hurt’s stomach in Alien. However, the most terrifying moments here come when the humans are waiting for them to appear, desperately hoping that they won’t. Lady Bird is one of the best American coming-of-age films since Barry Levinson’s Diner. Written and directed by Greta Gerwig, it offers an utterly winning mix of humour, poignancy and sharp-eyed social observation. Gerwig approaches her subject matter with the same tenderness and affectionate irony with which the adolescent Lady Bird regards Sacramento. Gerwig also shows Lady Bird’s heroism as the young heroine strives against the odds to become the very best version of herself she can be.If Phantom Thread is indeed Daniel Day-Lewis’s final film as an actor, he is going out on a wondrously bizarre note. This must be the oddest film in his career, one in which he gives a typically commanding but very idiosyncratic performance. Almost everything here is jarring – but generally in a very positive way. It is not so long ago that Paul Schrader seemed to be giving up on cinema. The American writer-director (whose credits include Taxi Driver, American Gigolo and Affliction) had taken to making movies like the sour Hollywood satire The Canyons with Lindsay Lohan and the cartoonishly violent Dog Eat Dog, shot cheaply, aimed at a VOD audience. The former had a montage of closed-down movie theatres. In interviews, Schrader struck a gloomy note about the future of the industry. This is why First Reformed is so refreshing. This is not just Schrader’s best film in a very long while. It is also a re-affirmation of the director’s belief in the medium.Oscar Wilde goes to ruin in Rupert Everett’s debut feature as director. Everett also wrote and stars in the film, giving a grandstanding performance as the Irish writer at the end of his life, after his release from prison, where he has been doing hard labour for “gross indecency”. He’ll be the film’s villain.Angela Lansbury as The Balloon Lady: Her character appeared in P L Travers’s original series of books.Meryl Streep as Topsy: As a nod to the “I Love to Laugh” sequence from the original, Streep has a cameo as the owner of a shop filled with trinkets. There’s one quirk: the first Monday of every month, her entire house turns upside down.Dick Van Dyke has made a return appearance, though not as Bert. He instead stars as Mr Dawes Jr, the son of Mr Dawes Sr – another character Van Dyke played in the 1964 film &nbsp– and chairman of the Fidelity Fiduciary Bank.The original Mary Poppins won’t make an appearance in the sequel, as director Rob Marshall explained: “Julie was incredibly gracious, and we talked about it in a very general way but she made it clear right up front. She said, ‘This is Emily’s show, and I really want it to be Emily’s show. I don’t want it to be, 'Oh, here comes that Mary Poppins.' I don’t want that. I really want her to take this and run with it, because she will be brilliant.'The film has Andrews’s full approval, however, as Marshall added: “She had known it was in the works, then we said, ‘We’re doing it,’ and she said, ‘Oh, thank god.’ Then we said, ‘And we’re thinking of Emily Blunt,’ and she just threw her hands up in the air and said yes. I think a lot of people feel that way about Emily’s work.The film, directed and produced by Rob Marshall, best known for Chicago and Into the Woods, brings the story forward to the era of the Great Depression, with a now grown-up Jane and Michael Banks living in their old house. After the death of Michael’s wife leaves him as a single father to three children, and throws their world into chaos, the Banks’s former nanny makes a return visit, with the help of lamplighter Jack.While 1964’s Mary Poppins draws mainly from the first book in P L Travers’s eight-part Mary Poppins series, the sequel focuses on an original story, which draws elements from several of the books.Mary Poppins Returns is an all-out musical, including new songs written by Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman, best known for the Broadway musicals Hairspray and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, and an original score by Shaiman. There will also be dance numbers, including one which takes place on the streets of London, set to the new song “Trip a Little Light Fantastic”.The film features several sequences that, much like the original’s “Jolly Holiday” segment, place live actors into an animated world. One sequence will see Mary and the children e into a bathtub and arrive in an underwater world, while another has them jump into a Royal Doulton bowl.Mary Poppins Returns will be released in UK cinemas on 21 December.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? title: no deal brexit consumers face catastrophic consequences which research
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsGovernment's preparations for a no-deal exit suggested a reduction in consumer rights and choice as well as price hikes that would have a “direct and hard” impactClick to followThe IndependentThree in five (61 per cent) expected disruption to food supplies because of hold-ups at the border,Millions of consumers could face “immediate” and “catastrophic” consequences in the event of a no-deal Brexit, the watchdog Which? has said.The consumer group said the government's preparations for a no-deal exit suggested a reduction in consumer rights and choice as well as price hikes that would have a “direct and hard” impact in areas ranging from travel to food and energy.The watchdog, which based its conclusions on its assessment of the government's technical notices in preparation for the event of a no-deal Brexit, online forums and surveys, said two in five people did not understand the potential implications of a no-deal scenario.Health department cannot guarantee 'supply of medicines' after BrexitIn its report - Brexit no deal: a consumer catastrophe? - Which? says: “Our latest consumer research shows that most people are unprepared for what 'no deal' would mean in practice - and many do not understand how it would have multiple impacts across so many aspects of their daily lives.“When the everyday repercussions and government's plans on issues such as food and medical supplies were explained to people in our research, many people were shocked and questioned why they had not been made aware of the implications sooner.”A survey for the watchdog found three quarters of people thought it was likely a no-deal Brexit would lead to higher prices for food and other items (76 per cent) and delays at the border for travellers and holidaymakers (75 per cent).McVey refuses to back May's Brexit plan ahead of crunch cabinet talksBrexit running on ‘naivety’, says former UK ambassador to EUTheresa May faces ministers as DUP threaten alliance over BrexitThree quarters (75 per cent) also thought no deal would make it harder to resolve an issue with a faulty product bought online from an EU-based business, while 70 per cent believed it would be more difficult to rely on protections in a European country if travel companies collapse.Which? director of policy Caroline Normand said: “Consumers want a Brexit that protects and enhances their rights and gives them access to a wider range of high-quality, affordable goods and services.“But it's clear that many are deeply concerned about what a no-deal Brexit would mean for families and businesses across Britain.“From grounded flights and delays at borders and airports, to food shortages and soaring energy prices, the impact could be immediate and catastrophic for millions of people, with disruption on a scale not seen since the consumer chaos of the 1970s.“The Government must agree a deal with the European Union to prevent a disaster scenario for consumers that hits them in the pocket and sees valuable rights effectively snatched away from them.”Populus surveyed 2,056 UK adults online between August 3-5 and 2,100 UK adults online between 19-20 September.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe research attempts to deal with a paradox that occupied the scientist's mind throughout his careerClick to followThe IndependentProfessor Stephen Hawking speaks at a media event to launch a global science initiative at The Royal Society in LondonStephen Hawking's final paper has been published, and it shows him grappling with one of the universe's strangest mysteries.It deals with the information paradox, a difficult question that had occupied Professor Hawking throughout his life. And in the very last days of his life he may have made important work towards solving it once and for all.That question revolves around the way that black holes are thought to swallow up and destroy anything that falls into them. If they do entirely destroy them, they would take the information about them behind – but it is thought to be impossible for that information to simply disappear, leading to the paradox.Created with Sketch.The most incredible space images of Earth Show all 30Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Explore ESA astronaut Tim Peake's stunning photos of Earth, taken from the International Space Station during his six month mission (captions by Tom Peake)Every day spent living in space is a great day, but today was particularly special. I got to speak with one of my inspirational heroes Prof Stephen Hawking and his amazing daughter Lucy, who developed the Principia Space Diary to engage children with STEM subjects. With that, they appear to take the information with them, but it cannot simply be lost without breaking the laws of quantum mechanics.But the new paper suggests that can be explained by the phenomenon of soft hair. That is a sort of glossy edge&nbspthat sits at the edge of the black hole and allows for scientists to overcome the paradox.Hawking memorial sees professor's voice shot into a black holeNow the researchers who worked with Professor Hawking on the paper in his final days will have to explore more of how exactly that works without him. Hawking, Malcolm J. Perry and&nbspAndrew Strominger –&nbspdescribes that process in far more technical detail. The summary concludes with a sentence that reads: Assuming the existence of a quantum Hilbert space on which these charges generate the symmetries, as well as the applicability of the Cardy formula, the central charges reproduce the macroscopic area-entropy law for generic Kerr black holes.But at its most simple level it could be part of a solution to a problem that has occupied many of the greatest minds in the world for decades, according to researchers.“Understanding the microscopic origin of this entropy – what are the underlying quantum states that the entropy counts? – has been one of the great challenges of the last 40 years,&nbspMarika Taylor, professor of theoretical physics at Southampton University and a former student of Hawking’s, told , which had first reported the new paper.This paper proposes a way to understand entropy for astrophysical black holes based on symmetries of the event horizon. title: spotify netflix blocked brexit no deal watch eu blocked uk british holiday latest
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsEU regulations currently ensure people can get to their home libraries even when abroadClick to followThe Independent TechSpotify&nbspmusic, Netflix&nbspshows and content on other online streaming services could be blocked to British citizens on holiday in Europe if the UK leaves the EU with no deal, the government has admitted.At the moment, ‘portability’&nbspregulation ensures that streaming services are not allowed to discriminate between someone when they are at home in the UK or if they are travelling to the rest of Europe. Users can go on holiday to France and still have full access to the&nbspNetflix films and Spotify&nbspmusic they get at home, for instance.But a tranche of newly-released official&nbspdocuments about the anticipated impact of a no-deal Brexit includes a paper that suggests the portability&nbsparrangement that exists with the bloc would “cease to apply”.Created with Sketch. Show all 9Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Brexit Resignation: July 10th 2018 Maria Caulfield MP Conservative Party's vice chair for women July 10th 2018Brexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conservative MP for Bolton West Chris Green MPBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conor Burns MP next to Boris JohnsonBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Steve Baker, EX-Minister at the Department for Exiting the European UnionBrexit Resignation: July 8th 2018 MP David Davis Ex-Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union Brexit Resignation: July 10th 2018 Maria Caulfield MP Conservative Party's vice chair for women July 10th 2018Brexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conservative MP for Bolton West Chris Green MPBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conor Burns MP next to Boris JohnsonBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Steve Baker, EX-Minister at the Department for Exiting the European UnionBrexit Resignation: July 8th 2018 MP David Davis Ex-Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union “This means online content service providers will not be required or able to offer cross-border access to UK consumers under the EU Regulation,” the papers make clear. “UK consumers may see restrictions to their online content services when they temporarily visit the EU.”The rules were agreed in 2017 and have been in force since April.Netflix made clear that its customers would still be able to access the service in the event of a no-deal Brexit. But when they do so they will most likely see the library of the country they are in, as happens if Britons travel outside of the European Union now.“UK Netflix subscribers are able to access Netflix everywhere in the world Netflix is available and will continue to do so once the UK leaves the EU,” a Netflix spokesperson said. The company said that “local catalogues vary due to licensing and local tastes”, but pointed out its original shows are available everywhere.The new papers also make clear that the same regulations would apply to geo-blocking regulation. That ensures that people can buy from online services across the continent, without being punished for doing so from another country.“Following repeal of the Geo-Blocking Regulation in the UK, traders from the UK, EU and third countries would not be prohibited from discriminating between EU customers and UK customers,” the papers say.“For instance a UK trader would be able to offer different terms to a UK customer compared to a French customer.”Companies based in the UK and selling products and services in the EU&nbspwill still have to comply with the regulation, to ensure that they don’t discriminate between people in different countries within Europe.The new geo-blocking rules go into effect in December 2018, meaning that they will apply to UK citizens for about&nbspthree months before a possible no-deal Brexit in March 2019.The paper covering ‘Geo-blocking of online content if there’s no Brexit deal’ and another covering portability of content&nbspis one of a range of papers released in the latest set of documents from the UK government. They also include new documents showing Britain could no longer benefit from deals that represent a significant portion of UK trade and that train journeys into and out of the EU could be disrupted.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? But, as part of ongoing austerity measures, they have been frozen since April 2016, resulting in a decline in&nbsptheir real term value while inflation rises.Now, if this year’s inflation reaches the predicted 2.7 per cent when revealed on Wednesday, it will mean the worth of working age benefits has fallen by an astonishing 6.4 per cent over the last four years.The foundation says some 10 million people will be affected, and called on the government to use the upcoming budget to cancel the freeze.Adam Corlett, its senior economic analyst, said: While the prime minister this week repeated her claim that austerity is over, significant cuts in support for millions of low-income families are set to continue next year as a result of the ongoing freeze in working age benefits.The budget represents a last chance to cut short the benefit freeze. could be the face of the new note.The decision concerning the figure on the front of the £50 will emerge in the coming months following public suggestions, and will ultimately be made by Bank of England governor Mark Carney.The last crop of fifties was introduced in 2011, and its future looked uncertain after concerns were raised about it being used for money laundering and tax evasion.However, the Treasury insisted the new batch will scupper criminals by being much harder to forge.First introduced in 1981, there are currently 330 million £50 notes in circulation, with a combined value of £16.5bn, the Treasury said.The exchequer secretary to the Treasury, Robert Jenrick, said: “Our coins and notes are respected and recognised the world over and are a key part of the UK’s heritage and identity.“People should have as much choice as possible when it comes to their money, and we’re making sure that cash is here to stay.Everything you need to know about the greatest ever black Briton“Our money needs to be secure and this new note will help prevent crime.”Besides the furore over who will feature on new notes, the Bank of England has been forced to defend its new polymer notes after animal rights activists noted they contain traces of animal fat.Campaigners argued that the use of tallow, a substance derived from fat and used to make candles and soaps, placed vegetarians and people from certain religious backgrounds in a difficult position.However, the Bank said that not only is polymer cleaner and allows for extra security features to be added, it is IndependentBritish fishing boats would have to warn of visits to European Union (EU) ports and have their catches inspected by officials after a no-deal Brexit, new documents have revealed.UK-registered vessels will no longer have an automatic right to land fish in any EU port if Britain leaves the without an agreement, the paperwork states.The details are set out in a raft of guidance published by the government that outlines a no-deal scenario at the end of March when Britain leaves the bloc,&nbspcovering areas ranging from farming and fishing to exporting horses.Some companies advised to relocate headquarters in no-deal BrexitStreaming services could be blocked for Britons in EU after BrexitA no-deal Brexit is against the ‘will of the people’The paper on fishing states that non-UK-registered vessels will no longer enjoy automatic access to UK waters.&nbspBut it continues:&nbsp“UK-registered vessels will no longer have an automatic right to land fish in any EU port.”British boats “will have to notify their intention to visit an EU-designated port and present information relating to the vessel and catch on board”, the document warns.“UK vessels may be subject to inspection: this could include a full document check, inspection of the catch and, where information has been provided electronically, database checks, it states.&nbspSimilarly, foreign boats, including EU vessels, would be subject to equivalent access rules at British ports.The&nbspEU will also require UK exporters to issue a catch certificate with each consignment of fish or fishery products it receives.&nbspFishermen’s leaders have previously warned a no-deal Brexit could threaten the industry.The government also warned the movement of horses between Britain and the EU for racing or breeding could be stopped.Current rules require an animal “passport” and a health document, and government officials are trying to convince the EU to let the UK become a “listed third country” on 29 March. But the warning says that if this does not happen, horses could not be taken into the bloc.EU certification would require more work by vets to confirm the absence of disease, the paper notes, which could cost up to £500 more if blood tests are needed, depending which category the UK was placed in.Created with Sketch.Tories at war: Boris Johnson 'suicide vest' Brexit jibe causes ide Show all 14Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Internal isions in the Conservative Party have exploded into a bitter public row over Boris Johnson‘s “disgusting” criticism of Theresa May.Sajid Javid, the home secretary, rebuked his former cabinet colleague and said: “I think there are much better ways to articulate your differences.”But other MPs leapt to Mr Johnson’s defence, as iding lines ahead of a possible leadership contest begin to take shape. The Uxbridge MP has repeatedly criticised Ms May’s Chequers plan and used a newspaper article on Sunday to suggest it amounted to “wrapping a suicide vest around the British constitution”. His latest salvo at the prime minister prompted immediate condemnation, with one minister publicly vowing to end Mr Johnson’s career over the matterAlan Duncan, a foreign minister who worked in Mr Johnson’s team for two years, wrote on Twitter: “For Boris to say the PM’s view is like that of a suicide bomber is too much. This marks one of the most disgusting moments in modern British politics. Housing secretary James Brokenshire added his voice to the criticism, calling Mr Johnson’s comments ”wrong”But as Tory hostilities spilled over into open public warfare, Richmond Park MP Zac Goldsmith, an ally of Mr Johnson, hit back at Mr Duncan.Senior Tory Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg told The Independent he thought Mr Johnson’s “suicide belt” accusation was little more than “a characteristically colourful catchphrase”.Nadine Dorries, another Brexit supporter, said Mr Johnson’s opponents were “terrified of his popular appeal”, adding: “Don’t underestimate the vitriol that’ll be directed towards Boris today. He delivered the Leave vote, Remainers and wannabe future PMs hate him.”Andrew Bridgen said Ms May was to blame for her leadership problems.Steve Baker, the former Brexit minister, warned Ms May the Conservatives faced a catastrophic split if she did not jettison her Chequers plan.The deep isions on the Tory benches were laid bare as Tom Tugendhat, who chairs the Commons foreign affairs committee and is a possible leadership rival to Mr Johnson, also hit out at the former foreign secretary.Alistair Burt, another Foreign Office minister who worked in Mr Johnson’s team, said: “I’m stunned at the nature of this attack. There is no justification for such an outrageous, inappropriate and hurtful analogy. Marina had endedThe British Veterinary Association warned it could mean a surge in demand for members at a time when the workforce was already facing significant shortfalls in capacity.In a recent BVA survey, two-thirds of vets who are qualified to sign export health certificates said they were not planning to renew their qualification.In the event of no deal, owners would need to apply for a new government-issued identity&nbspdocument if they wanted to move horses to the EU that were not registered on a studbook or pedigree register or with a national branch of an international organisation for racing or competition.Bringing horses from Europe into Britain would not change.The official documents say a no-deal scenario is unlikely and negotiations “are progressing well”, but it adds: “However, it’s our duty as a responsible government to prepare for all eventualities, including ‘no deal’, until we can be certain of the outcome of those negotiations.”To import and export items including caviar, snowdrops, orchids, corals, reptiles and alligator skins used to make bags and watch straps, new licences would be needed, according to a paper on moving endangered species.It outlines how the UK would comply with international obligations under the Convention in International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (Cites), a treaty that protects wildlife.Items in annex B of the treaty, which can be freely traded at the moment in the EU, are among those that would need to follow the same processes as those currently in place for movement between the UK and non-EU countries.Anyone importing species from the EU would need to ensure that suitable facilities were in place for handling live animals, the document warns.Importers would have to take care to use “an appropriate land, sea or air port for the shipment”.High-risk food and animal feed would need to be checked entering the UK without a Brexit deal.The UK would also lose access to the systems for exchanging intelligence about food alerts between EU countries, the papers reveal.&nbsp“If the UK leaves the EU in March 2019 with no deal in place, the UK will no longer be able to rely on the EU undertaking full import controls on high-risk consignments transiting through the EU to the UK. The goods will therefore need to be checked as they enter the UK,” they say.The Food Standards Agency plans to require all importers of high-risk food and feed from the EU to warn them using a new UK import notification system.All the new guidance documents have the caveat: “This notice is meant for guidance only. PoliticsExisting agreements that deliver 12 per cent of the UK’s total trade will be lost if there is a no-deal Brexit, the government has admitted.Trade agreements enjoyed with scores of other countries, through EU membership, will “cease to apply” if the UK crashes out of the EU next March.The government said it would attempt to replicate the deals “as soon as possible thereafter” – but admitted those “third countries” would have leverage to demand better terms.May abandons pledge for 'time limit' on UK's stay in customs unionUntil fresh agreements could be struck, exports and imports to these countries would fall under World Trade Organisation rules – and be subject to tariffs.The admission came as the department for exiting the European Union (DExEU) released the final batch of technical papers, to prepare the public and businesses for a chaotic BrexitThe Food and Drink Federation immediately condemned the “shambolic” prospect of a no-deal exit – warning of higher shop prices and a huge loss of jobs, if tariffs were imposed.And the British Chamber of Commerce said it underlined the need for the UK and EU to break the deadlock “as soon as possible, to avoid the confusion and significant disruption of a no deal scenario”.The UK boasts around 40 free trade agreements, with more than 70 countries, because it is an EU member, including the United States, Canada, Switzerland, Turkey and NorwayThey give businesses “a range of preferential market access opportunities”, including cheaper import tariffs and duties and more relaxed “rules of origin” requirements.The deals also provide “enhanced market access” for services, “public procurement opportunities” and “improved protections for intellectual property”, DExEU said.The Independent revealed story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe daily newspaper Sabah&nbsppurports to publish the names, photos and travel movements of 15 Saudi nationals it says arrived in Istanbul just hours before the Washington Post journalist disappearedClick to followThe IndependentA Turkish newspaper has published the names, faces, and travel movements of what it describes as the 15 Saudis allegedly involved in the disappearance of a prominent journalist who vanished in Istanbul last week. Then, online sleuths reportedly managed to use open-source material to identify at least eight of those allegedly involved in the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, a 59-year-old Saudi journalist, as members of Saudi security forces. One photo purported to show a member of the 15-member team hobnobbing with Mohammed bin Salman, the powerful 33-year-old Saudi crown prince who has become the primary target of&nbspMr Khashoggi’s criticisms. Another identified an alleged team member as Salah Mohammed al-Tubaigy, a name and face matching the head of forensic evidence at Saudi’s General Security department.Sabah purports to identify the 15-member Saudi team allegedly involved in the disappearance of journalist Jamal KhashoggiThe details&nbspwere published by Sabah, a mass-circulation daily newspaper close to the government of president Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Friends, family, and officials say Mr Khashoggi was lured to the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on 2 October before disappearing.&nbspTurkish media reported that security camera footage from inside the consulate was removed and that staff were ordered to go home the afternoon Mr Khashoggi arrived.On the same day, two private jets, owned by Riyadh based Sky Prime Aviation,&nbspreportedly arrived from Saudi Arabia to Istanbul’s Ataturk airport, carrying the 15 personnel, landing just hours before Mr Khashoggi’s scheduled appointment at the consulate. Some of the 15 checked in to the five-star&nbspMovenpick&nbsphotel near the Saudi consulate in Istanbul’s Levent district.&nbspBoth private jets and the 15 men departed hours later, according to Turkish officials and local press. Khashoggi: Emergence of Saudi dissident and his potentially tragic endTurkish authorities investigating the disappearance of Mr Khashoggi, a prominent Saudi with Turkish ethnic roots, have been leaking information about the probe to local and international media with what appears to be the tacit approval of government officials.Police in Istanbul have formed a special team to investigate Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, the newspaper Milliyet reported, tasked specifically to use chemicals, dogs, and infrared light to look for DNA, blood and other traces of the journalist at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.The Post and other media also circulated a photo, likely taken from security camera footage, showing a black Mercedes Vito van that was parked outside the consulate and left shortly after Mr Khashoggi’s arrival, parked in front of the residence of Saudi consul general Mohammad al-Otaibi.The 15-member team identified by Sabah are all Saudi men aged between 30 and 57 years old. Those purportedly tracked down via open source internet tools by Oslo-based researcher Iyad al-Baghdadi and others include: a Saudi special forces member a lieutenant colonel in the Saudi civil defence force a major and lieutenant in the Saudi air force a lieutenant in the service guarding the crown prince’s palace and an intelligence service colonel who had once been attached to the Saudi embassy in the UK.Kalin on the disappearance of a Saudi journalist Jamal KhashoggiMr Khashoggi served for years as the right-hand man of Saudi prince Turki bin Faisal, a former intelligence chief as well as Riyadh’s envoy to the US and UK.&nbspIncreasingly frustrated with Saudi Arabia’s&nbspcourse, he began to bristle at the restrictions placed on media and civil society, eventually moving to the US last year amid fears for his own safety. In recent months he had grown increasingly critical of the crown prince, who has been criticised as authoritarian despite attempts to cast himself as a reformer. Saudi officials have denied that they had anything to do with Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, insisting he left the consulate, but without providing proof, as demanded by Mr Erdogan.&nbspThe disappearance of Mr Khashoggi, a permanent US resident, has put Washington in a tough spot. The crown prince has forged a strong alliance with the administration&nbspof Donald Trump and a personal bond with the US president’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner. US lawmakers have made tough statements about the Khashoggi affair, but the White House and State Department have been tepid. Saudi Arabia has vowed to buy $110bn in American weapons.“We’re not going to make any judgments about what had happened to him,” Heather Nauert, State Department spokeswoman, told reporters on Tuesday. “The United States is certainly concerned about his whereabouts. Senior officials at the State Department have spoken with Saudi officials through diplomatic channels about the matter. story: EU leaders have struck a far more positive tone in recent days, just three weeks after they flat-out rejected Mrs May&rsquos soft Brexit plans - based on the so-called Chequers agreement - at a summit in Salzburg.The Irish border issue remains the biggest hurdle still to overcome, but a shift in the UK&rsquos position over the &lsquobackstop&rsquo contingency plan has opened the door to a possible deal at next week&rsquos European Council summit.But the Prime Minister will be forced into a delicate balancing act in the coming days as she attempts to address calls by Brexiteers in her Conservative Party, who are pushing for a clean break from Brussels, while keeping her unionist allies in Northern Ireland happy.Mrs May relies on votes from the Democratic Unionists (DUP) to maintain her slim majority in the Commons but the party&rsquos leader Arlene Foster said the DUP would stand by its red line on the constitutional and economic integrity of the UK come what may.READ MORE: Theresa May releases 29 NO DEAL Brexit consequences on BritainFollowing the Prime Minister&rsquos disastrous performance in 2017's snap election, she negotiated a &lsquoconfidence and supply&rsquo deal with Mrs Foster&rsquos party, which traded &pound1billion in extra funding for Northern Ireland for support from the DUP on key issues.Mrs May could attempt to secure the unionist votes she needs to force a deal through the Commons by offering more money - potentially tens of millions of pounds - in exchange for support for her plans.But a senior DUP policymaker told the Daily  that money will not solve the problem.They said: Money to sip poison to the Union slowly isn't exactly a great offer.Brexit news: Theresa May could secure a draft exit deal next week (Image:  IMAGES)The Prime Minister is trying to keep the DUP and Brexiteers happy while pursuing her Brexit plans (Image: REUTERS)                'Never agree!' May to REFUSE Brexit deal trapping UK under EU rule                'Theresa May needs to go NOW' Brexiteer demands she resign IMMEDIATELYTory Brexiteers have been calling for Mrs May to change tack on her plans for the spilt since she revealed her Chequers blueprint in July.And her proposals for the Irish backstop, which would see the entire UK continue to abide by the EU&rsquos customs union rules, have been condemned for having the potential to keep Britain shackled to Brussels for years to come.One possible solution for Mrs May would be to strike an agreement with the EU that both sides will have the&nbspability to jointly agree when they are ready to move to the new deal.But this could be a non-starter because of the Prime Minister&rsquos commitment to ensuring there are no trade barriers between Northern Ireland and Great Britain after Brexit - and a customs union is the only feasible option at this late stage.Mrs May relies on the 10 votes provided Arlene Foster's DUP to maintain a Commons majority (Image: EPA)A potentially more workable option would see Mrs May focus on the future UK-EU trading arrangement.The Irish backstop will only kick in if other terms are not agreed, so the PM could put all of her energy into securing an ambitious trade deal which leaves the door open to technological solutions in the future.The prospect of eventually developing an &lsquoinvisible&rsquo border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic may be enough to keep both Brexiteers and the DUP happy, though Brussels has already poured cold water on the customs plans in Mrs May&rsquos Chequers deal.Britain is scheduled to leave the EU on March 29, 2019, but Brussels has agreed to an 18-month transition period designed to give businesses the chance to adapt.Brexiteers like Jacob Rees-Mogg would likely resist attempts to extend the transition period (Image:  IMAGES)On the current timetable, the transition will end on December 31, 2020.But the Prime Minister could request an extension to buy more time to negotiate a trade deal with the EU, removing the need for the backstop and placating the DUP.However this option would likely go down badly with Brexiteers who have warned any extension of the transition could pave the way for the UK remaining tied to Brussels indefinitely.If these softer approaches fall flat, Mrs May could be forced into a showdown with the Brexiteers and the DUP.

story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will forge a different path to the royals who have gone before them when they embark on a 16-day tour of Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand, arriving in Sydney on Monday ahead of the 2018 Invictus Games - created by Harry - in support of wounded servicemen and women.Speaking to Express, royal commentator Richard Fitzwilliams is predicting the Commonwealth tour will be a &ldquobrilliant success.He believes Meghan Markle and Prince Harry will &ldquoundoubtedly boost support for the monarchy in both Australia and New Zealand during times of political uncertainty in the southern hemisphere.Mr Fitzwilliams added they will bring huge appeal to the royal family, particularly among younger people, and can become a &ldquodynamic duo and be among the world&rsquos most successful charitable workers.                Meghan Markle told to DELAY Commonwealth tour in SHOCKING rebuke                Meghan Markle and Prince Harry glow as they return to WindsorThe royal expert said: Harry and Meghan will undoubtedly boost support for the monarchy in both Australia and New Zealand where there are extremely strong republican movements though the changeover of prime ministers in Australia has been alarmingly rapid and the continuity the monarchy embodies is, in contrast, extremely valuable.&ldquoHarry&rsquos marriage to Meghan is proof that here have been huge changes in the monarchy and this likely to have a huge appeal, especially among the young.&ldquoThey are likely to become a dynamic duo and be among the world&rsquos most successful charitable workers with their inspiration taken from Diana and from the Queen&rsquos dedication to duty.&ldquoMy prediction is that the tour will be a brilliant success.Mr Fitzwilliams spoke to Express about his most memorable royal tours, ning nearly 70 years:Meghan Markle and Prince Harry are set to embark on their first royal tour as a married couple (Image: )Queen and Prince Philip&rsquos Commonwealth tour, 195354Since becoming Queen in 1952, the head of the royal family has visited every Commonwealth country at least once.Her first and longest tour lasted six months between November 1953 and May 1954, which covered over 40,000 miles and that took her to several Commonwealth states, including the West Indies, Australia, Asia and Africa.Together with her husband Prince Philip, she first spent two days in Bermuda and on February 4, 1954, opened the Parliament of New South Wales in Australia - marking the first time a sovereign opened a parliament in the country.She also visited Sri Lanka and opened the Parliament in Colombo, ending her trip in Gibraltar, and despite the visit being made against a backdrop of a territorial dispute between Britain and Spain regarding ownership of Gibraltar, she received a warm welcome from the thousands there to greet her.Commenting on the reception the Queen and Prince Philip received, Mr Fitzwilliams said: The six-month Commonwealth tour of 195354 by the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh is probably unsurpassed for the unparalleled enthusiasm with which they were greeted as well as for its length. Nothing quite like it had previously been seen.                Meghan Markle and Harry tour: 76 engagements in 16 days &ndash FULL DETAILS                All the details of Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's Australia tour The Queen and Prince Philip are entertained by Queen Salote Tupou III of Tonga (Image: )Princess Diana and Prince Charles&rsquo tour of Australia and New Zealand, 1983The Prince and Princess of Wales embarked on their first official tour of Australia and New Zealand in March 1983.The touched down at Alice Springs Airport, with Diana pictured holding baby William before they were pictured in front of Ayres Rock - arguably one of the most iconic royal photographs ever.Princess Diana and Prince Charles, flanked by bodyguards, were driven through Sydney and past the famous Opera House to thunderous cheers from thousands of people lining the streets.The royal couple were pictured dancing at a charity ball in Sydney, and met then-Prime Minister Bob Hawke and his wife Hazel in front of the Government House in Canberra, before meeting crowds in Brisbane and Perth.They were also greeted by thousands of people at Eden Park in New Zealand and took a ride in a Maori canoe.Mr Fitzwilliams said: During the six-week tour of the Prince and Princess of Wales to the Antipodes in 1983 adoring crowds yearned to see only her and this caused more difficulties in her already fraught relationship with Charles. This tour was pivotal to Diana&rsquos development as a superstar.Princess Diana and Prince Charles' picture in front of Ayers Rock was an iconic moment (Image: )Queen and Prince Philip&rsquos state visit to Ireland, 2011The Queen and Prince Philip made a three-day state visit to the Republic of Ireland from May 17-20, 2011, at the invitation of then-President of Ireland Mary McAleese.The visit to Ireland was significant because it came a century after the last visit by a British monarch, when her grandfather King George V visited from July 8-12, 1911 as part of his accession tour.It was seen as a symbolic normalisation of relations between the UK and the Republic of Ireland following the signing of the 1988 Good Friday Agreement, which settled most outstanding territorial dispute.Arrangements included the security operation in the history of the Republic of Ireland, which saw the Queen visit sites of significance for Irish nationalism in Dublin, such as the Garden of Remembrance and croke Park, the seven of the 1920 Bloody Sunday massacre.Mr Fitzwilliams said: One of the high points of her reign was undoubtedly her state visit to Ireland in 2011, she was the first British monarch to have visited Ireland for a century and it marked a seminal moment in the peace process and a turning point in the attitude of Sinn Fein towards the crown.&ldquoThe Queen gave a greeting in Gaelic at the State Banquet in Dublin Castle which caused the Irish President, Mary McAleese, to gasp, and the visit was a huge success.The Queen's visit to Ireland came a century after the last visit by a British monarch  (Image: )Prince William and Kate Middleton&rsquos tour of Canada and the US, 2011The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge went on their first royal overseas tour together in June 2011 - just two months after getting married.Thousands of Canadians flocked to the capital Ottawa for their arrival, while a record 1,400 journalists and photographers from across the globe covered the visit in June and July.Prince William and Kate Middleton also took part in a dragon boat race on Prince Edward Island and wore 10-Gallon cowboy hats as they opened the Calgary Stampede rodeo.In Los Angeles, California, William, in a tuxedo, and the Duchess, in a flowing lilac Alexander McQueen dress, enjoyed Hollywood glitz and glamour at a BAFTA reception with Hollywood actresses Jennifer Lopez and Nicola Kidman.Mr Fitzwilliams said: The tour of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge to Canada and Los Angeles in 2011, their first, was extremely high profile and a huge success with a skilful blend of the formal and informal as was their visit to the Antipodes with George as a scene stealer in two public appearances in 2014.Kate Middleton and Prince William wore cowboy hats as they opened the Calgary Stampede rodeo (Image: )Meghan and Harry&rsquos tour of Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New ZealandThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex are preparing for their first major trip abroad - just five months after they married in a glittering ceremony at St George&rsquos Chapel, Windsor.The whole 15-day trip will largely be centred around the Invictus Games, which begins on October 20 and before that, they will open the new Taronga Institute of Science and Learning, and will travel by boat across the Sydney Harbour to the Sydney Opera House to watch a rehearsal of Spirit 2018 by the Bangarra Dance Theatre.Meghan and Harry will visit Government House in Melbourne before they return to Sydney to watch and present the Invictus Games, attending the opening ceremony in the evening.On October 22, they will travel to Queensland&rsquos Fraser Island and will take part in a traditional Welcome to Country Smoking Ceremony and unveil a plaque for the dedication of the Forests of K&rsquogari.The following day, they will fly to the Fijian capital of Suva, attending an official welcoming ceremony, known as the Veirqaraqaravi Vakavanua, which will mirror the format of the one attended by The Queen and Prince Philip in 1953.The Duke and Duchess will also lay a wreath at the Fiji War Memorial, and will meet a number of Fijian war veterans.Meghan and Harry's first tour takes place just five months after they married (Image: )The couple will then fly to Tonga, where they will visit Consular House in central Nuku'alofa for a private audience with His Majesty King Tupou VI and Queen Nanasipau&#699u and will attend an exhibition with Princess Angelika at the Faonelua Centre, celebrating Tongan handicrafts and products.Meghan and Harry will return to Sydney to attend the Australian Geographic Society Awards before spending their final day in Australia at the Invictus Games and the closing ceremony.They will fly to New Zealand and be greeted on arrival in Wellington by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern before enjoying enjoying a traditional welcome ceremony on the lawns of Government House, and will visit Pukeahu National War Memorial Park to visit the memorials and have a walkabout.In Aukland, Meghan and Harry will join the Prime Minister to visit Pillars, a charity operating across New Zealand that supports children who have a parent in prison, before returning to Aukland on October 31 and returning to London.Mr Fitzwilliams said: &ldquoHarry and Meghan&rsquos first Commonwealth tour is obviously extremely significant and will be given huge international coverage.Meghan and Harry's first Commonwealth tour is extremely significant said Richard Fitzwilliams (Image: )&ldquoPivotal to it is the fourth staging of Harry&rsquos wonderful initiative, the Invictus Games, for disabled, injured and sick service personnel which they will be supporting in Sydney.&ldquoHarry is Commonwealth Youth Ambassador and the emphasis on this tour will be on youth leadership and projects which help or involve young people.&ldquoMeghan&rsquos first solo engagement, at the recent opening of the Oceania exhibition at the Royal Academy in London, links to the tour as did her charming choice of the 53 Commonwealth floral emblems which were embroidered on her exquisite wedding veil.&ldquoShe will promote female empowerment, an issue close to her heart, during the tour too.

title: royal wedding princess eugenie wedding bouquet westminster abbey grave
story: Princess Eugenie's Royal Wedding has been sent to Westminster Abbey  (Image:  )The bride's bouquet was sent to Westminster Abbey, just like royal brides before her including the Queen, Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, and most recently Meghan Markle.&nbspThe gravestone commemorates an unidentified British soldier who died on the battlefield during the First World War, a symbol for all those who have died during the conflict.The Queen's mother began the tradition in 1923 after she married King George IV, when she laid her bouquet on the gravestone as she made her way into the wedding ceremony.She did this to commemorate her brother, Fergus, who died in 1915 during the Battle of the Loos, as well as marking her respect for those who lost their lives during the war.                Royal wedding LIVE: Eugenie and Jack attend Queen's reception befor...                Princess Eugenie and Jack could have ROYAL BABY in THIS yearWestminster Abbey tweeted: The bouquet carried by Princess Eugenie at the #royalweddding yesterday has been sent to rest on the Grave of the Unknown Warrior here at Westminster Abbey.&ldquoThis royal wedding tradition was started by The Queen Mother and remembers fallen soldiers.The pretty bouquet was put together by floral designer Patrice Van Helden Oakes and featured lily of the valley, white spray roses and ivy to name a few.But as well as being pleasing to the eye, the formation also followed royal custom.The bouquet featured myrtle, which as first carried by Queen Victoria&rsquos daughter of the same name when she married in 1856.The flower is used to represent the traditional innocence of a bride, and is a tradition for a royal bride's bouquet.The shrub has been selected many times in the decades since, with Eugenie&rsquos mother, Sarah Ferguson, also opting for it when she married her now ex-husband Prince Andrew in 1986.The Queen also followed the tradition in 1947, when she was known as Princess Elizabeth, carrying a sprig myrtle in her bouquet on her wedding day.She carried a floral display of white orchids when she tied the knot with the Duke of Edinburgh at Westminster Abbey in 1947.In 1920, the Reverend David Railton, a First World War army padre, decided to bring back an unknown soldier back to the UK, as a representation of all military personnel who had died in the conflict.The grave remains a powerful symbol, embodying sacrifice and suffering of British soldiers, and remains the only memorial in the Abbey which is never walked over.

title: brexit news second referendum people s vote EU theresa may
story: Any additional vote would take at least five months to prepare meaning even if one were announced next month, Britain would not be ready to leave the EU as planned in March 2019, research by&nbspUniversity College London (UCL) found.The study comes as Mrs May attempts to steer Britain out of the bloc in the face of a series of threats to her plans for a soft Brexit which could provide the catalyst for a second referendum.This week the Prime Minister&rsquos Democratic Unionist Party allies warned they would vote against any deal which separated Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK as Brexiteers in the Tory party continue to call for Mrs May to chuck Chequers.Meanwhile, recent polling suggests a growing number of people are supportive of a final say on the vote while Labour members voted overwhelmingly to leave the door open to a second poll at the party&rsquos conference last month.                Thirty Conservative MPs gang together to DEMAND another Brexit voteThe experts behind the report, produced by UCL&rsquos Constitution Unit, acknowledged the prospect of a so-called People&rsquos Vote is contentious but said it would be perfectly achievable given the political will.The in-depth study examined exactly how a second referendum could come about, its legal implications and what sort of question would be most suitable.It also considered potential timelines of a second vote, with the report authors warning a minimum of 22 weeks would be needed to prepare the ballot - and even longer if the public were asked a &lsquomulti-choice&rsquo question.The authors found Brexit could be delayed by at least six months in a scenario where the Prime Minister secures an exit deal and wins the backing of MPs but her EU Withdrawal Bill is held up by the House of Lords.Brexit news: Any second referendum would delay Britain's planned exit from the EU, research shows (Image:  IMAGES)A second Brexit referendum would take at least 22 weeks to prepare, the study found (Image:  IMAGES)If the House of Lords demanded a second vote, the referendum may not take place until September 2019 (Image:  IMAGES)                Brexit second referendum will NOT set precedent for Scotland                'Brexit BULLY boys!&rsquo Soubry claims she will not be DROWNED outIn this scenario, if peers demanded the public have a final say on whether to leave with the deal, leave without a deal or stop Brexit and remain in the EU, a referendum would not take place until September at the earliest.If the electorate then opted to leave with the deal negotiated by Mrs May, the 18-month transition period keeping Britain tied to the EU would begin in six months later than planned.During the transition, which under the Government&rsquos current timetable would end on December 31, 2020, the UK will be bound by Brussels&rsquo rules but have no say over the drafting of new ones.In a scenario where a second referendum does not take place until September, the transition would run until mid-2021 - meaning the UK could be chained to the EU for almost another three years.Assuming the UK is able to strike an exit deal with the EU, Mrs May will still be faced with a series of major obstacles before it becomes law.Parliament has demanded a &lsquomeaningful vote&rsquo on the orce deal, and the Prime Minister&rsquos slim majority - plus her reliance on votes from her unionist allies in Northern Ireland - means she could fall at the first hurdle.But even if her Brexit plan survives the meaningful vote, MPs could still insist the public be given a final say.Dr Alan Renwick, report co-author and Deputy Director of the Constitution Unit, said: &ldquoThe principle of a further referendum on Brexit is likely to remain controversial, so it is of utmost importance that the process should command the maximum legitimacy.&ldquoIf the result is to be accepted by those on all sides, every effort should be made to ensure the referendum campaign is fair, the poll is properly conducted, the options put to the referendum are clear, and the question allows voters to express their preferences unambiguously.Professor Meg Russell, report co-author and Director of the Constitution Unit, said: &ldquoIn the British system anything is possible given the political will. The current level of interest in a further referendum on Brexit makes it vital that serious consideration is given to all possible scenarios, including which would work best and which would be most problematic.

story: Brexit news: Support grows for Norway-style deal in UK (Image: )A so-called &lsquosoft&rsquo Brexit is favoured by 43 percent of Britons, making it the country&rsquos most popular Brexit option, according to the Policy Institute at King&rsquos College London.The Norway-styled Brexit would see Britain remain a member of the European Economic Area, which would mean continued membership to the EU&rsquos single market.Jonathan Grant, professor of public policy at King&rsquos College, said: &ldquoAs we approach the cut-off date for finalising a Brexit deal, it appears that more and more people are seeing a close relationship between the UK and the EU as a good thing.&ldquoWhile there may be political difficulties in implementing what our research found to be the most popular type of deal &ndash one that resembles membership of the EEA &ndash it is clear that the public place a high value on a soft exit.The research also suggests Remain have turned the tables on Leave and would a second Brexit referendum.Fifty-two percent of the survey&rsquos participants would vote to stay in the EU, which is up from 48 percent in 2017 and the actual 2016 referendum.Charlene Rohr, Senior Research Leader at RAND Europe, said: While the referendum delivered a result to leave the EU, it is&nbspsimply not possible to know from this outcome what sort of relationship with the EU Britons wanted.&ldquoThe aim of our research is to use choice experiments to quantify what aspects of this relationship the British think are most important and what trade-offs people would be willing to make&nbspto inform Brexit negotiations.                Brexit news: Secret plans could see UK remain EU rule-taker after 2020Top secret talks between UK and EU officials may deliver a solution which pleases the subjects of the King College&rsquos research.High-level discussions between European Commission and UK negotiators have produced theories that would see the country remain a &ldquorule-taker in order to solve the thorny Irish backstop issue.The plans would see the so-called transition period extended beyond December 2020, meaning Britain would be forced to accept the bloc&rsquos rules while remaining a member of its single market and customs union.While the proposal is yet to be put in writing by either side, the worked clause would mean Britain would have to fork up more money to the so-called Brexit orce bill, which currently stands at &pound39bn.Under current implementation plans, Britain&rsquos transition from the EU will last 21 months and enables both sides to agree a future partnership while avoiding a &ldquocliff edge.Officials from both sides believe an offer of an extended stay for the British would provide a solution for Theresa May to convince Arlene Foster&rsquos Democratic Unionist Party the Irish backstop would never be triggered.The DUP currently stands in the way of the Prime Minister&rsquos plan to allow a number of checks between Northern Ireland and Great Britain in a bid to convince Brussels a UK-wide backstop is acceptable.The party&rsquos 10 MPs, who prop up Mrs May&rsquos minority Conservative Government, are preparing to vote against the upcoming Budget if they disagree with the Brexit deal.

story: THERESA May stands by her June proposals (Image: Jack TaylorGetty Images)A Downing Street spokesman today made it clear that the Prime Minister will not agree to staying in the EU&rsquos customs union for a period without a time limit.The proposal had been mooted as a solution to the so-called Northern Ireland backstop to resolve the problem around the land border with Ireland.But after Mrs May failed to persuade senior members of her cabinet on the solution while others including Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab have made it clear they would resign, Mrs May has ditched the suggestion.There are also serious questions whether Mrs May could get the proposal through parliament with the powerful European Research Group of Tory Brexiteer MPs set to vote against anything that stops Britain from &nbspagreeing its own free trade deals. any such backstop could leave the UK in an open-ended customs union, preventing it from seeking trade deals elsewhere in the world.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson has said it risks making the UK a permanent EU colony.Meanwhile, Chancellor Philip Hammond became the first senior Government figure to suggest that the backstop - designed to keep the border between Northern Ireland and the Conservative administration in the House of Commons, urged her to resist any initiatives from Brussels which might threaten the Union.DUP Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson said there would be consequences for Mrs May if she walked away from her promise to protect the Union.We are simply reminding her, you are being torn at the moment between what we believe are your gut instincts and your sound principles on the Union and at the same time the bullying, threatening behaviour of the EU, said Mr Wilson at a meeting of DUP MPs and Assembly members in Portadown.Go with your principles, go with your instinct, go with your responsibility to the people of the UK and show the EU negotiators the door.BREXIT negotiations: Theresa May and European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker (Image: EMMANUEL DUNANDAFPGetty Images)Mrs May chaired a meeting of the inner Cabinet on Brexit progress Mrs May set out in June proposals for a temporary customs arrangement to ensure that the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic remains open in the case that no broader EUUK trade agreement has been finalised.The document stated that the UK Government expects this arrangement to remain in place no later than the end of December 2021.But the EU is mounting resistance to any specific time limit being included in the text of the UK's Withdrawal Agreement, while Leave-backing ministers are understood to be insistent that the end of the arrangement should be more precisely defined than the vague term temporary.Earlier, Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, who was not at the Downing Street meeting, pointedly refused to endorse the Prime Minister's Chequers blueprint for Brexit.International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt and the Leader of the Commons Andrea Leadsom - who, like Ms McVey, both backed Leave in the referendum in 2016 - were also said to harbour deep concerns.A number of ministers, including Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, Environment Secretary Michael Gove and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, were said to have raised concerns over the backstop issue during the 90-minute meeting.&nbsp

story: Speaking to Euronews, the Christian Social Union (CSU) MEP argued the result of the Bavaria regional election depended on the unresolved issue of migration in the Brussels bloc.&nbspAngela Merkel's ally claimed it was time Europe delivered a solution to the migration problem and stopped feeding populists around the bloc.&nbspMr Weber said: &ldquoWe saw all over Europe that the migration question is the dominating issue in the campaigns.&ldquoAnd we are at the moment suffering as CSU from this debate.                Merkel will be blamed for 'dramatic' Bavaria election on Sunday&ldquoI think what we have to do is give people an idea that we have a solution.&ldquoWe can solve the problem.&ldquoThat means, first of all, that Europe must deliver.&ldquoAt the European Council meeting next week I expect results on this question because otherwise, we will feed the populists if we cannot give a proper answer.Voters will take to the polls on Sunday to elect the 180 members of the 18th Landtag of Bavaria.Bavaria election: CSU Manfred Weber pleads for EU's help to win Bavaria election (Image: &bullEURONEWS)The regional elections could weaken the national government if the CSU is not successful and blame is placed on Horst Seehofer, who is Ms Merkel&rsquos Interior Minister and leader of the CSU.The CSU, which is Ms Merkel&rsquos coalition partner and Bavarian sister party to the CDU, will be contesting the vote on October 14 against the Alternative for Germany (AfD) anti-immigration party.The AfD has surged in popularity with anti-Islamic rhetoric and attacks on Chancellor Angela Merkel's migrant policy - a hot topic in Bavaria, where most of the 1.5 million asylum seekers who reached Germany in the past three years entered the country.The party&rsquos rise has decimated support for Mrs Merkel's Bavarian allies the Christian Social Union (CSU) which is set to lose the absolute majority with which it has controlled the southern state for most of the post-war period.The loss of the CSU&rsquos absolute majority in Bavaria would put yet more pressure on Mrs Merkel&rsquos crisis-torn coalition Government and could potentially lead to its downfall.A poll published by German broadcaster ARD last week showed support for the CSU had fallen to 33 percent, despite usually getting around 50 percent of the vote.The poll showed the Greens Party in second place, with 18 percent voter support.This was ahead of the Social Democrats, who were at 11 percent, with the far-right AfD slightly behind with 10 percent.As a result, this could be the CSU&rsquos worst performance since 1950, when it received 27.4 percent of the vote.

title: when clocks go back 2018 british summer time
story: Even though everyone tries to remember to set their alarms correctly, it always catches a few people out. So here is our handy guide to help you remember when to reset...The clocks will go back again on Sunday, October ,  which marks the end of daylight saving time and theto Greenwich Mean Time .GMT is the mean solar time at the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, London.The change heralds the approach of winter by ensuring there’s more daylight in the evenings and less in the mornings.To avoid confusion, many use the phrase spring forward, fall back to remember when the clocks change.The clocks went forward at am on Sunday, March , .As the clocks go back, at am on October  to be precise, you will gain an hour - either for more partying or extra sleep.Your smartphone and other internet-connected devices like tablets and computers will often change the time automatically instead of requiring you do it manually.Whether Daylight Saving Time is effective is the topic of much debate.Despite trying other methods of clock-changing, such as double summer timeand a permanent British Summer Time , the current method has remained in place since .Supporters say it reduces traffic accidents in winter, saves energy, boosts tourism and encourages more people to exercise outdoors.The golf industry says one extra month of Daylight Saving Time can generate up to £.million a year in extra sales and fees.Critics claim darker mornings are dangerous for children walking to school and say the energy-saving argument is invalidpeople use fans and air-conditioning in the warmer months.A YouGov poll in  found  per cent of Brits support moving clocks forward permanently, while  per cent oppose the change.When permanent BST was trialled in northern Scotland from  to , a record number of people were killed or seriously injured.Daylight Saving Timewas created by William Willett in  in a bid to stop people wasting valuable hours of light in the summer months.By setting the clocks back in winter, Brits get an earlier sunrise and earlier sunset.In summer the sun rises and sets one hour later than it would without DST.In a pamphlet called The Waste of Daylight Willett suggested clocks should be advanced by  minutes over four stages in April, and reversed the same way in September.Willett died of the flu in  and Germany adopted his clock-changing plan on April  the following year.Britain followed suit one month later on May , as World War One was underway.The Summer Time Act of  was passed by Parliament and the first day of British summer was reported as May , .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
