It also provides a final and exquisite stitching underpinning the tapestry woven through three of his other great Scottish histories: To the Ends of the Earth, Scotlandrsquos Empire and Independence or Union.Throughout his latest work Professor Devine challenges an assortment of other questionable narratives including the one that holds that the mass of depopulation in the Highlands was caused by the Clearancesand that it was mainly English landlordism and English factors who were responsible. None of this of course diminishes the full extent of the inhumanity and human greed that laid waste to entire communities across Scotlandanything it amplies them.The concept of reparative justice,applied to the Scottish Clearances, would be howled down by those families and institutions which benefited most from the greed and exploitation of their ancestors: ldquoIt was too long ago, ldquowhatrsquos to be gained, ldquoit only feeds a culture of grievance. You hear similar sentiments espoused by the landownersrsquo organisations which represent the  iniduals who own more than half of Scotland. That many of them benefited from illegal land grabs in an era of political, religious and judicial chaos seems never to have given them any cause to reflect on this let alone make amends. In any case, they aver, they are better stewards of the land and few but them know how to thrive in these wild places. They werenrsquot always wild though, and entire communities once lived in them.The University of Glasgow has pledged to initiate a y and sensitive journey of amendment not simply to acknowledge its slavery past but also ldquoto engage in the kinds of reparative justice most appropriate to a university based on Enlightenment ideals of truth and justice. This will include establishing deeper links with the University of the West Indies and funding exchange programmes and scholarships with communities throughout the Caribbean.The university was just one of many Scottish institutions which benefited from the proceeds of human wickedness and greed. How many banks, insurance companies, shipping firms, private schools and grand Scottish mansions ndash and the families who live in them ndash were also enriched because their ancestors treated black people worse than animals  If, in two yearsrsquo time none have felt the need to follow a similar course to that taken by the University of Glasgow then Scotlandrsquos claims to be a country where truth, justice and enlightened attitudes thrive will have been eroded.When injustice and inhumanity is permitted to occur on a grand scale only a small and powerful elite benefit. If theyrsquod had to share the proceeds of their dishonesty and cruelty they wouldnrsquot have bothered. This is why their descendants and the political causes they support are the loudest in protesting that any moves to denude them of some of the wealth they inherited from the reset of stolen goods. Yet no-onersquos asking them to pay it all back: nothing remotely like it. All that wersquod ask of them is that they undertake the same self-examination as the University of Glasgow and perhaps fund some social programmes for those who suffered most from their familiesrsquo dishonesty and brutality.Andthey refuse to do this voluntarily then perhaps an enlightened, liberal and socially progressive government like, oh, I donrsquot know ... like our SNP Government, could ensure that it happened anyway. A first step would be to establish a Justice Commission which would name and shame the modern-day beneficiaries of theft, murder and illegal land-grabs both here and in those countries where our ancestors caused so much suffering. An index of those families and institutions which were built on slavery and which have refused to acknowledge this must be established and published. Customers could then decidethey wanted to favour such institutions with their business.Another way, of course, would be simply to ensure that a preferential option for the descendants of those worst affected in Scotland underpinned our Governmentrsquos social policies. That is, of course,we want a sense of fairness to guide the way Scotland conducts its business.

title: alcohol-free-drinking-festival-targets-scotlands-heavy-drinking-over-50s
story: Writing on the online forum Soberistas, "Tfers" outlines a common problem. Although rarely drunk, she still drinks at least double the recommended limit every week, she says."I am really keen to cut my drinking right down or quit."I just have a real problem with visualising social situations with no alcohol."This is a major concern, according to experts.In fact, finding ways to socialise and activities to take part in away from alcohol is not easy ndash testament to the nations problematic relationship with drink."I live in the West of Scotland, whereyou dont drink, people assume there is something wrong with you,"Tfers added.An alcohol free mindful drinking festival at Glasgows Briggait today will attempt to kick start a change in that culture.A first for Scotland, the free event is organised by online support group Club Soda ndash after successful similar festivals in London.Read more:Older problem drinkers denied help, says reportThe event is being backed by the Drink Wise Age Well campaign , a lottery funded initiative to tackle the problem of excessive drinking among the over-s.It is this group which throws up some of the most worrying statistics about Scotlands drink culture, and where people are most resistant to change.Drinking above the UK governmentrsquos recommended guidelines is declining in every age group bar the over s.Counter to general trends, many people increase their drinking in later le, sometimes because they struggle to adapt to retirement, or becoming empty-nesters with more time to fill after children have left home. Some drink more after losing a partner and being left alone.An estimated , Scottish over s are putting themselves at risk due to heavy drinking. "Drinkers aged - in Scotland are more likely to exceed the recommended weekly guidelines than any other age group," says Julie Breslin, head of the DWAW programme. Worryingly, only a minority are receiving help with this."Read more:Tough measures on under-age drinking open parents eyes"Around  per cent are drinking at home, alone. It is a very hidden population."Alarmingly,they do seek help, they may face discrimination from health services, she adds. "They can be viewed as too old to change and are more likely to be offered medication than talking therapies, or other support."While this group tend to be resistant to change, viewing them as impossible to influence is misguided, she says. "We know that for  per cent of late-onset drinkers alcohol begins to become a problem after the age of , so it is wrong to write them off as too late to change or because the damage is already done."Some are overlooked by health experts because they are not drinking at levels deemed harmful - but in fact they are because their age means they could still be causing themselves signicant damage, she says.DWAW is calling for specialist older adult services and experts within existing treatment services. "Resources are tight, but the ageing population is going to grow and grow. We cant leave this group isolated and forgotten."Meanwhile groups like Soberistas reach people who would never go near an addiction clinic or Alcoholics Anonymous, she says. Club Soda, like Soberistas, grew from grassroots online support for those looking for ways to cut down on their drinking while not feeling abnormal.Glasgows Mindful Drinking Festival will offer visitors a chance to sample the wares of non-alcoholic drink providers, try mocktails made by expert mixologists and find out about alternative alcohol-free drinks to challenge the soft drink monotony of cola or orange juice.Read more:Older women drinkers putting their health at risk, survey findsThese days, the alternatives are vast - from no-sin gin to kombucha , and from alcohol-free cocktails to craft ginger beer.With nothing available above the legal limit of . per cent alcohol, participants can even take the kids along.Club Soda co-founder Laura Willoughby MBE said since the first festival in London last year, she had had immediate requests from iniduals and organisations in Glasgow to bring the event to Scotland.ldquoThe most common request we get is for ideas about what to drink instead of alcohol, so we have curated our favourites, and created an event for everyone. The festival is great for those going sugar-free, on a fitness regime, drinking more mindfully, or going alcohol-free."There are many reasons why people may want to swap out a few alcoholic drinks for something a bit healthier.

title: benefits-freeze-to-cost-families-200
story: The Resolution Foundation said the latest inflation figures, due out on Wednesday, would illustrate the ongoing impact of the freeze in working age benefits.The living standards think-tank called on Chancellor Philip Hammond to use this monthrsquos Budget to cancel the final year of the four-year freeze announced by predecessor George Osborne in .Benefits are by default increased in April each year in line with the inflation figure from the previous September.But since April , working age benefitsndash including Child Benefit, Tax Credits, Universal Credit, Housing Benefit and Jobseekerrsquos Allowance ndash have been frozen in cash terms, meaning their real termsvalue declines every year as a result ofinflation.The CPI inflation rate was . per cent in August andthat figure remains stable then the impact of the freeze will see the average low-earning couple with children effectively lose pound next year, while the average single parent in the bottom half will lose pound next year.The average loss for households in the bottom half of the income distribution will be pound next year, with the cumulative impact of the four-year freeze amounting to a pound lossnext year.It will mean the value of working age benefits falling by .% over the last four years, compared to a forecast of .%.The Resolution Foundation says thatmore than  million households ndash including . million children, .million disabled people and , people looking for work ndash willbe affected.Based on a .% inflation figure, thefreeze will save the Exchequer pound. billion in -, far more than the pound.bn originally forecast.Adam Corlett, senior economic analyst at the Resolution Foundation, said: ldquoWhile thePrime Minister this week repeated her claim that austerity is over, signicant cuts insupport for millions of low-income families are set to continue next year as a result of the ongoing freeze in working-age benefits.ldquoOn Wednesday we will learn the full scale of next yearrsquos benefit freeze, with an average lower-income family with children on course to lose over pound a year.ldquoThe Budget represents a last chance to cut short the benefit freeze. Scrapping it would send a strong signal that, from the perspective of low-income families, the Government is committed to ending austerity.A Government spokesman said: ldquoWersquore committed to providing families with the support they need, which is why we spend poundbn a year on working-age benefits, and we will be spending poundbn more on all welfare by  than we do now.ldquoThe reality is there are now one million fewer people living in absolute poverty compared with , including , fewer children.ldquoAt the same time, we have supported more people into work, introduced the National Living Wage, doubled free childcare and helped workers keep more of the money they earn at the end of every month by cutting taxes for  million people.Shadow work and pension secretary Margaret Greenwood said: ldquoThis is yet more shocking evidence that Theresa May is failing to keep her promise to end austerity.ldquoTodayrsquos report shows pound.bn in cuts areyet to come from the Toriesrsquo benefitfreeze alone.ldquoOnly Labour will end austerity and transform our social security system so thatit provides security and dignity for all.

title: noses-are-backartist-moves-away-from-galleries-to-launch-own-website
story: Later, Scottish artist Joe OrsquoBrien took his chance with galleries which paid off and allowed him to showcase his talent.ldquoI came down from the mountain, away from the jail and thought lsquoIrsquom going to risk rejectionrsquo and go into galleries," he says.ldquoLo and behold galleries picked up on me and started selling my paintings.Now, he is making a comeback after five years away from the mainstream and is embracing technology.The -year-old self-taught painter has decided now is the perfect time to take his work online.With the encouragement of a friend, he has recently launched his own website. Joe describes his work as ldquosymbolist or surreal and admits that it does not hang comfortably in everyonersquos living room.He took the decision to remove himself from galleries when they tried to get him to change his art and ldquopaint less noses and more cottages.Working from a small studio on Alexandra Parade in Glasgowrsquos east end, he has decided to sell to the wider public again to ldquosustain his creativity and keep up processing the journey and storytelling.ldquoAn agent picked me up and some paintings sold to Scottish celebrities ndashMichelle Mone and Muriel Gray ndash I was delighted with that, he says of his initial big break.ldquoIt kept me in house and home but then I had a kind of crisis of confidence where galleries were concerned because they were starting to try and shape my way of painting.ldquoThe paintings were selling but they were saying lsquowe can sell more of themyou paint less noses and more cottagesrsquo.Laughing, he insists he has no problem with paintings of cottages, but it just isnrsquot his style.ldquoI donrsquot paint comfortable art, I donrsquot paint art that generally speaking sits well above the sofa.ldquoAlthough, what is an absolute delight is that children seem to love them. On the one hand galleries were implying the paintings might frighten children and on the other hand I was finding children, young people and lots of adults were delighted with them. I built up a core following of people who for whatever reason love my work and kept buying them.ldquoBut, I became disillusioned with galleries and withdrew.However, it was important to keep working in the background.He says: ldquoMy paintings are interesting to me first and foremost and that keeps me painting and they are interesting to that core group of followers ndash that allowed me to withdraw from galleries.ldquoWhat was keeping me going was private commission and private sales. That was a fantastic feeling that people want to buy my art.He feels now is the right time to explore a new avenue to sell his work and keep him motivated.ldquoRecently, a friend who wanted to work with me for some time and is very supportive recommended internet, online sales, the whole shebang and I said, lsquoI think the time is perfectrsquo, he says.ldquoThe website has now been launched. Irsquom not a total dinosaur with the computer but note overly well versed in it.ldquoI think itrsquos going to be a very useful way of me being able to sustain my creativity, keep up processing storytelling and getting my art out to people who might appreciate it.ldquoI donrsquot want to alienate galleries but I lost a lot of faith in some of them at least and this is a better way for me to acquire some kind of control over what Irsquom doing and that leads in to why Irsquom doing it as well.Joe spends as much time as he can in his studio overlooking Alexandra Parade in Glasgowrsquos east end.He says: ldquoI come in here as often as I can,the mood takes me I can get off a bus from Maryhill or even walk it.ldquoTherersquos times Irsquove walked when Irsquom feeling the urge to batter away on a big painting - or a wee one, or think that face needs another nose.ldquoIrsquom self taught, Irsquove got loads of pals that went to art school. I did consider doing that but Irsquove had friends tell me that in their opinion theyrsquore glad I never went.ldquoAlthough I admire the discipline they learned, they greatly admire my playfulness.ldquoIf Irsquom creating something, does it really matter what technique is used as long as itrsquos the outcome I want

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: NOT staying next door to the conference venue in such palatial style was Humza Yousaf. Indeed, the Justice Secretary arrived almost half an hour late for one breakfast fringe because of a troubled commute. But he did have an excuse ready. The former transport minister was able to gleefully blame his successor in the job, Michael Matheson. Handy.HUMZA also managed a zinger against the fringersquos host, the Scottish Police Federation. The coppersrsquo union usually ambushes justice secretaries at these events, but decided to lay off Mr Yousaf after getting a .% pay rise. ldquoItrsquos no less than they deserve, he told them. ldquoItrsquos less than we deserve, joked SPF general secretary Calum Steele. At which Mr Yousaf shot back: ldquoThat means your negotiating skills arenrsquot very good then. Ooft. Truncheoned.THE Justice Secretary went on to recount his curious upbringing. While his mother was a Labour supporter, his dad was the first non-white member of the SNP. ldquoMy dad would have the SNP poster upstairs, my mum would have the Labour poster downstairs. Was there a LibDem one in the middle  asked the chair. ldquoThere was no LibDem poster in the house, Mr Yousaf deadpanned. ldquoThe only place yoursquod find a LibDem poster would be on the fence.THERE were more revelations at a fringe held by the SNP Socialists. One of the audience said she was trying to get her partner to join the party. ldquoThatrsquos what we call horizontal recruitment, said Glasgow councillor Graham Campbell from the chair, ldquoI was recruited by Anne. At which a mortied Anne McLaughlin, the former MP for Glasgow North East, exclaimed: ldquoGraham! It certainly puts those , new members in a dferent light.AT the same event, Chris Stephens, MP for Glasgow South West, revealed he was a student of Game of Thrones. ldquoThe Scottish Tories answer to Ramsay Bolton, he said, referring to one of the TV showrsquos most repellent psychopaths. ldquoRoss Thomson not only looks like him but acts like him. The eyes bulging, the veins sticking out the neck as lsquoSNPrsquo leaves his lips. Mr Thomson, the Brexiter MP for Aberdeen South, is an obsessive dog owner. Perhaps Mr Stephens was trying to warn him  Ramsay Bolton, after all, was eaten by his hounds.HOLYROODrsquoS annual Festival of Politics concludes today with a potentially fascinating session with Anas Sarwar. The Labour MSP recently discovered hersquod been sacked from the shadow health portfolio by reading about in on Twitter. By exquisite coincidence, he is due to take part in a discussion on ldquoPolitics and Social Media, and how Twitter affects democracy. His unique insights will no doubt have Richard Leonard hanging over his phone for updates.

title: independent-scotland-would-be-welcomed-back-into-eu-labour-grandee-says
story: David Martin ndash the second longest-serving MEP in Europe ndash said sympathy was growing in Brussels over Scotland being ldquoforced out of the EU against its will.He said negotiations would be ldquoquick given Scotland would meet nearly all of the conditions for membership, and argued a ldquobespoke deal would enable it to stay out of the eurozone.Scottish Labour dismissed his remarks as "hypothetical statements which do not reflect Scottish Labour policy in any way, shape, or form.Mr Martin said Scotlandrsquos future membership of the EU was not ldquohigh on peoplersquos agenda in Brussels, but added: ldquoIt is talked about, and there are people who would not previously have been sympathetic to the idea of an independent Scotland ndash colleagues of mine, Irsquom talking non-British colleagues ndash who now talk about it openly and say to me, lsquoAre you going to be an independent country, are you likely to join as a separate country rsquoldquoI think there is a dference between now and the time of the Scottish referendum where we were seen to be leaving a member state and we were pulling ourselves out of the EU in some peoples eyes.ldquoThis time around weare being forced out of the EU, which is how it is perceived here.ldquoThey know that Scotland voted to Remain and I think they would be very sympatheticScotland came back and said, lsquoScotland became independent and it wants to join the EUrsquo. It would be welcome.He said a bespoke deal on joining the euro would be offered ldquobecause other countries have it and it wouldnrsquot be a problem that you didnrsquot sign up to the euro.A major SNP report earlier this year suggested keeping the pound for at least ten years after independence, before moving towards a new currency.It insisted Scotland would not be obliged to join the euroit became a member of the EU, pointing to the example of other countries such as Sweden and Denmark.Mr Martin, a Labour MEP since , said plans to keep the pound ndash as outlined in the SNPs Growth Commission report ndash would probably be accepted by Brussels.He said Scotland would not have to queue behind others seeking to gain membership ndash such as Montenegro, Serbia and Albania ndash but would ldquohave to nevertheless go through the process of the negotiation and fulfill all the conditions.Mr Martin previously refused to rule out backing independence in order to secure links with Europe.A Scottish Labour spokesman insisted his remarks did not reflect party policy.He added: ldquoIf Brexit has made one thing clear, it is that there are severe challenges in leaving a political and economic union. All of the challenges we see with leaving the EU would be repeated on a much larger scale with leaving the UK.An SNP spokeswoman said: ldquoBrexit means there is now a much more positive view of an independent Scotland among our European friends and neighbours.ldquoAnd the Toriesrsquo shambolic handling of Brexit has killed off the credibility of any future lsquoProject Fearrsquo campaign against independence.ldquoScotland has been part of the EU for  years, meaning we already meet the rules, so we would be very well prepared to join as an independent nation."

title: first-scottish-female-film-director-to-be-honoured-at-national-film-theatre
story: But now the le and career of Scotlandrsquos first female film director is being celebrated with a major retrospective of her work, being organised by the British Film Institute to mark the centenary of her birth next month.Orcadian Margaret Tait was a distinguished poet, writer and filmmaker, who made history as the first female Scots director of a feature- film.ldquoTaitrsquos unique mix of image, sound, rhythm and poetry reminds us of what cinema is and can be, explained a British Film Institute spokesperson.Described by the acclaimed Scots playwright Ali smith as ldquoa unique and underrated filmmaker, Tait was born in Kirkwall on  November  and later moved to Edinburgh to study medicine, serving with the Royal Army Medical Corps in India and the Far East during the Second World War.After the war she moved to Rome to study film at the prestigious Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia, and made her first short film, One Is One, in Italy in .In  she ed to Scotland, settling in Edinburgh and founding Ancona Films, eventually making over thirty short films ranging infrom three minutes to over an hour, most of which examined everyday le in the city.She also published several books of poetry.ldquoThe kind of cinema I care about is at the level of poetry, she explained. ldquoIn fact, it has been in a way my lersquos work making film poems.Among her best known works are Hugh MacDiarmid: A Portrait, a documentary about Scotlandrsquos most famous th century poet, and Where I Am Is Here, both shot in Edinburgh in .Of the latter, Tait said: ldquoStarting with a six-line script which just noted down a kind of event to occur, and recur, my aim was to construct a film with its own logic, its own correspondences within itself, its own echoes and rhymes and comparisons, all through close exploration of the everyday, the commonplace, in the city, Edinburgh.Her work was noted for its impressionistic style and unique use of music. ldquoAlthough I donrsquot understand musical structure - I canrsquot really follow the structure of a piece of music when Irsquom listening to it - I think that film structure is more like musical structure than anything , she once said.But her films were perceived as having little commercial appeal and she struggled to attract the interest of film distributors.ldquoAs it turned out, of course, distributors then were not interested in independently produced short films. There was, in fact, not really a market at all, she admitted.Consequently, Tait had to finance almost all her films herself and, although she gained some favourable critical attention during her letime, her films were not widely seen by the public.In  she ed to her beloved Orkneys and worked as a locum to fund her short films, most of which focused on the relationship between Orcadians and the land and sea.Finally in , at the age of , she secured a budget to make her one and only feature- film, the first to ever be directed by a Scottish female director.Blue Black Permanent, which she had originally conceived in the s, starred Celia Imrie and explored the lives of three generations of women from an Orcadian family.She continued working almost until her death at the age of  in , her last project being the short film Garden Pieces.ldquoI actually picked up a camera in the last few days to work on something in the old style, meaning mm, self-produced and self everything , she said shortly before her death.Although regarded as something of a forgotten figure in Scotland, in recent years her role as a pioneer of Scottish filmmaking has begun to be more widely recognised, and in  the Glasgow Film Festival founded the Margaret Tait Award ldquoto support experimental and innovative artists working with film and the moving image in Scotland.Rhythm and Poetry - The Films of Margaret Tait - runs at selected independent cinemas around the country from  October until  November.The highlight of the season will be a special screening of a digitally remastered print of Blue Black Permanent at the National Film Theatre in London and the Glasgow Film Theatre on  November, to mark the centenary of her birth.

title: more-disruption-expected-as-storm-callum-batters-uk
story: Rail services were plagued by delays, with severe weather affecting services between Preston and Scotland, across Wales, and in South West England.Strong winds have seen speed restrictions imposed on many routes ndash with reduced Virgin services between London Euston, Birmingham New Street, and Edinburgh and Glasgow, Network Rail said.# With Storm Callum affecting many parts of Britain, were advising passengers to check travel plans at @nationalrailenqFind out how rain and strong winds impact the railway:# https:t.co MPywHlH#StormCallum #storm pic YpDvHqcJnJmdash Network RailOctober , Flooding and falling trees have seen major disruption across most rail services in Wales, while trains in Devon and Cornwall are also likely to be delayed.Motorists were also warned over tricky driving conditions brought by Callum.An amber warning for rain remains in place for parts of south Wales until pm, with further flooding and power cuts likely.A yellow warning covers much of the rest of Wales, as well as parts of Scotland and the north west and south east of England.Thousands of households were left without power and dozens of flights grounded on Friday as torrential rain and winds of more than mph buffeted the Republic of Ireland, Northern Ireland and the west coast of Britain.Here are the top gusts from Friday #StormCallum pic ZVbZARwmhwmdash Met OfficeOctober , One part of south Wales, the Brecon Beacons village of Libanus, recorded mm of rain in just  hours ndash way above the monthly total for the region of mm.Forecasters are warning of more of the same over the weekend, although some parts of England will escape the worst.Natural Resources Wales is warning people to be alert for more flooding as the heavy rain could see rivers continuing to rise on Saturday.Sioned Warrell, NRWrsquos duty tactical manager, said: ldquoWe have seen a signicant amount of rain over the last  hours and this will continue today.ldquoWe have already seen this impact on the roads and we could see more flooding as the rain flows down from the mountains.ldquoMaking sure you know what the situation is like where you live is really important.Met Office meteorologist Helen Roberts said: ldquoThere will be more wet and windy weather for similar parts of the country ndash predominantly western areas ndash which could cause more flooding.ldquoThe east and south east of England will see the best of the drier and brighter weather, where it will be even warmer than yesterday and could reach C ndash way above average for the time of the year.Overnight, several police forces reported accidents on the roads due to surface water, while Network Rail said it was expecting disruption to train services throughout Saturday and advised passengers to plan ahead.The Environment Agency has issued flood warnings for parts of the Dorset coast, as well as  flood alerts across England, while Natural Resources Wales has  flood warnings and  flood alerts in place.Storm Callum was named by Met Eireann and is the third named storm of the season to hit the UK.

title: young-singer-named-gaelic-ambassador-of-the-year
story: TheGaelic cultural festival started on Friday with aspecial celebration honouring Scotlandrsquos Year of Young Peopleat a ceremony in the Queens Hall in Dunoon, Argyll and Bute.The audience heard from the Royal National Modrsquos president Allan Campbell before traditional groups SIAN and Beinn Lee took to the stage for an evening of music.The groups were invited to perform at the ceremony as part of the Year of Young People celebrations, with all members in their twenties.Earlier in the day, the ldquoprestigious Gaelic ambassador of the year award was presented to -year-old Eilidh Cormack, from Portree on Skye.The award, presented by MSP Michael Russell, celebrated how much she has accomplished within the Gaelic community at such a young age, and what lies ahead for her in the future.She said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted to have been awarded with the Gaelic ambassador of the year at the Royal National Mod this year and I certainly wasnrsquot expecting it, especially being so young.ldquoItrsquos going to encourage me to not only look back and appreciate what Irsquove been doing and what the Mod have recognised, but also encourage me to keep doing it for years to come.In his speech, Mr Campbell paid tribute to the late John Macleod, who was president of theMod for  years and announced that An Comunn Gaidhealach, organisers of the Mod,will establish an annual lecture in his memory.The first annual John Macleod Memorial Lecture will take place in January  at the University of Edinburgh, where Mr Macleod studied Law.The lectures will be hosted by the Department of Celtic and Scottish Studies and will always be delivered by speakers under  years of age, in a nod to Mr Macleodrsquos enthusiasm and encouragement of young people in the Gaelic community.John Morrison, chief executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, said: ldquoWe are delighted to kickstart this yearrsquos Royal National Mod and are excited to showcase Scotlandrsquos best Gaelic talent once more.ldquoThe announcement honouring the late John Macleod is something we have been working to bring to fruition for some time, and we cannot think of a more fitting tribute for a man who offered so much to the Gaelic community in his time.ldquoThis year we are celebrating young people in our community, and we aimed to reflect this with our opening ceremony performers and co-host, as well as the deserving Gaelic ambassador of the year award recipient. Eilidh Cormack is an exceptional talent.ldquoWe are certain she has a bright future and that her role as Gaelic ambassador of the year will inspire others to follow in Eilidhrsquos footsteps.The eight-day festival will feature more than  competitions and events in Highland dancing, sport, literature, drama, Gaelic music and song, with Gaelic speakers of all levels competing.As well as the competitions, this yearrsquos Fringe showcases the best of Gaelic arts and sport with events for all ages, from ceilidhs to drama and several musical performances.

title: ben-fogle-tells-of-dark-cloud-after-climbing-everest
story: Commons Foreign Affairs Committee chairman Tom Tugendhat said the UK should work with its allies on its responsefollowing claims Jamal Khashoggi was killed while visiting the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.Mr Tugendhat said it was important to establish the facts, butthe Riyadh government had murdered Mr Khashoggi then there could be a downgrading of diplomatic relations and a boycott by UK ministers.Riyadh faces a chorus of international calls to shed light on what happened to the Washington Post columnist, and business leaders have already shunned the regime.In a sign of the international concern, UN Secretary GeneralAntonio Guterres said he wanted to know the truth about what happened and expressed fears such disappearances would happen more regularly and become a ldquonew normal.Financial Times editor Lionel Barber announced the newspaper would be pulling out of its partnership in a high-profile economic conference in Riyadh, while Sir Richard Branson has frozen several business links with the Gulf state.Mr Tugendhat said International Trade Secretary Liam Fox should boycott the Future Investment Initiative in Riyadh later this monthSaudi involvement in Mr Khashoggirsquos disappearance was proved.ldquoThe first thing for us to do is for us to get together with our allies, the United States, the Europeans and others, to discuss very seriously whatrsquos going on, Mr Tugendhat told BBC Radio rsquos Today.ldquoThe idea that we can treat Saudi as a normal stateit practises state-sponsored murder outside its borders is simply not true.He added: ldquoWe may be talking about downgrading diplomatic relations, we may be talking about restricting support for certain areas.Mr Guterres told the BBC at theInternational Monetary Fund meeting in Bali: ldquoWe need to have a strong request for the truth to be clear.ldquoWe need to know exactly what has happened and we need to know exactly who is responsible and, of course, when we see the multiplication of this kind of situation I think we need to find ways in which accountability is also demanded.Former foreign secretary Sir Malcolm Rkind called for Britain to impose sanctions against Saudi Arabia following the disappearance of a Saudi journalist.He told BBCrsquos Newsnight: ldquoIf the current Crown Prince remains in power for the indefinite future, then in the first instance the United Kingdom must work with the United States, France and other countries to seethere can be a combined response, a punishment of some kind, of sanctions of some kind.ldquoIf the United States was not willing to take part then the United Kingdom has to consider action that it will take in its own name.A critic of Saudi Arabiarsquos de facto ruler Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Mr Khashoggiwas living in self-imposed exile in the US and writing opinion pieces for the Washington Post before he vanished.He visited the consulate last Tuesday to obtain a document confirming he had orced his ex-we, in order to allow him to remarry.Turkish officials have said he was killed on the premises and his body removed.Saudi officials have denied the allegations as baseless.

title: bank-of-england-announces-new-50-print-run
story: It will be printed on the thin, flexible plastic material polymer after the Turner pound note is issued in , the Bank of England said on Saturday.The last crop of fties was introduced in  and its future was uncertain after concerns were raised about it being used for money laundering and tax evasion.# Breaking # Your pound notes will be going plastic just like the pound, pound and pound notes #There are  million pound notes in circulation More here # https:t.co PrGkhPV and what a pound looks like today # pic sRLBtdhGmdash HM TreasuryOctober , But The Treasury said the next batch will scupper criminals by being much harder to forge.A decision over what character will adorn the note will be made following public suggestions.First introduced in , there are currently  million pound notes in circulation, with a combined value of pound. billion, the Treasury said.The Exchequer Secretary to the Treasury, Robert Jenrick, said: ldquoOur coins and notes are respected and recognised the world over and are a key part of the UKrsquos heritage and identity.ldquoPeople should have as much choice as possible when it comes to their money, and wersquore making sure that cash is here to stay.ldquoOur money needs to be secure and this new note will help prevent crime.Last year, the Bank of England ignored calls from animal rights activists to ditch polymer notes that contain traces of animal fat.Polymer is cleaner, more durable, and allows for extra security features to be added, the Bank said, adding they are better for the environment as they last around . times longer than the paper equivalent.

title: grenfell-tower-soil-tests-reported-to-reveal-huge-concentrations-of-toxins
story: Professor Anna Stec, who conducted the study, is said to have found ldquohuge concentrations of potential carcinogens in the soil and dust around the west London tower block.The newspaper reported that the professor in fire chemistry and toxicity at the University of Central Lancashire warned senior health officials, the police and Kensington and Cha Councilof the need for further tests.Saturdayrsquosndash Revealed: lsquohuge concentrationrsquo of toxins around Grenfell site #tomorrowspaperstoday pic wAgQyPKEmdash Helen MillerOctober , She is also said to have found high levels of hydrogen cyanide in the soil she analysed.Professor Stec told theshe had taken a high number of samples from locations up to almost a mile away from the tower.She told the paper: ldquoAs a result of this work, I already have datasets that indicate a number of toxins that have not yet been measured by Public Health England , who have already looked into air quality.ldquoI think my research will show there are a number of added toxicants that need to be measured, but itrsquos important to emphasise that this work has not yet been completed ndash and we still need to carry out a lot of analysis before we can be completely sure of the implications.ldquoThe findings will need to be validated before they are published.Seventy one people died in the blaze on June  last year, with a nd victim dying months later in hospital.Last month, Professor Stec was instructed by the public inquiry into the blaze as an expert witness.She will provide a report to determine the fire derived toxicants and related deposits present in the tower and their origin.A spokesman for PHE said the agency had received a phone call from the professor but had not been briefed and had not seen the data.The agency has been monitoring the air quality around the tower and has consistently said it has found nothing of concern.A PHE spokesman said: ldquoLocal authorities are responsible for assessing and legally determining contaminated land within their communities.ldquoPHE is aware of Professor Stecrsquos preliminary research but it has not been shared with us and therefore we have not had the opportunity to review the evidence being referred to.ldquoPHE awaits the research with interest and will carefully consider the results.ldquoWe are continuing to fully support local health partners and the Grenfell community to ensure that they have access to best available public health evidence and advice for ongoing monitoring and surveillance of people directly impacted by the fire.An RBKC spokesman said: ldquoOur priority is the long term health needs of all those who have been affected by this terrible tragedy, and we will work with our health partners to examine carefully any new evidence about the impacts of the disaster on local residents.It was recently announced that Grenfell survivors and surrounding residents are to be given special screening to examine the effects of smoke inhalation and possible asbestos exposure, health chiefs have announced.NHS England said it would provide up to pound million to fund long-term screening and treatment for those affected by the Grenfell Tower fire.It follows calls from the Grenfell coroner, Dr Fiona Wilcox, for the NHS to set up a screening programme for those who were exposed to smoke and dust in the fire.

title: ex-strictly-star-walsh-and-jones-should-not-have-apologised-on-tv
story: Comedian Walsh and Jones appeared on the BBC Two programme on Wednesday to address the kiss, which had resulted in Walsh being publicly dumped by his partner Rebecca Humphries, and which also prompted speculation around Jonesrsquos marriage with Strictly dancer Neil Jones.Rihanoff told BBC Breakfast, of the pairrsquos highly-anticipated dance on Saturdayrsquos programme: ldquoThey have to be professional.ldquoThey are performers at the end of the day, and they have to put all of this aside, and letrsquos face it, there are much more dficult situationshellip last year, Alexandra Burke danced and her mother passed away, and Irsquom sure that was a real, real struggle to get herself together.ldquoSo yes, itrsquos been a terrible week but they have to get themselves together, and I donrsquot think It Takes Two was the right programme to say sorry.ldquoThe show is about dancing, not about private lives. They apologised on social media and Irsquom sure in private to all the partners involved, so I canrsquot really understand why the subject was brought up on It Takes Two.Rihanoff, who appeared in the BBC One show from  until , said that she hopes viewers judge Walsh and Jones for the routine rather than the events of the past week.She said they will be under ldquolots of pressure, adding: ldquoAt the end of the day, they are hired to do a job, they are both under contract, and they have to perform and the show is about dancing, it isnrsquot about personal lives, so they have to go out and I hope theyrsquoll perform their best tonight, andthey will be eliminated, let it be.ldquoHowever, I wish for them to go and to do the best they can possibly do.The -year-old dancer said the public will have the ldquoupper hand in whether they stay or leave this weekend, and recalled when she and political broadcaster John Sergeant were voted in week after week in  to remain, despite poor performances.She said she does not believe in the so-called Strictly curse, adding: ldquoThere are so many other reality shows that brings couples to either go apart, or get together ndash therersquos Irsquom A Celebrity, Big Brother. I just think Strictly is watched by so many more people.ldquoStatistically people get together at work, and thatrsquos where people work.Rihanoff said she could not see any similarities between Walsh and Jonesrsquos situation and that of her own.She is now in a relationship with rugby player Ben Cohen, who she was partnered with on Strictly in .In light of the story in todays newspaper I would like to offer my sincere apologies for my actions. This is no excuse but it was a one-off drunken mistake which I am truly sorry for.mdash Seann WalshOctober , They became a couple the following year, after Cohenrsquos split from his we of  years, and in  they welcomed daughter Mila.ldquoThe only parallel is that we met on the show but our relationship developed after the show, Rihanoff said.ldquoAnd also I have a family, I have a child and we are a family and thatrsquos what matters.Walsh and Jones will face the scrutiny of the public when they dance a cha cha cha on Saturday night, their first appearance since they were pictured kissing in The Sun newspaper last weekend.Strictly Come Dancing is on at .pm on BBC One.

title: bennachie saved from a96 dual plans
story: The option to create a dual carriageway through the Bennachie area has been scrapped by the Scottish Government.It has been removed following initial design and assessment work, and also feedback from the public.Initial options removed include the existing A Inverurie Bypass and the offline southern route between east of Huntly and Blackburn, which passes through the Bennachie Special Landscape Area.Local communities and road users in the Inverurie area have the chance to see and comment on the options being taken forward for further design as the Scottish government looks to identy a preferred route option next year.Public exhibitions will be held at Inverurie Town Hall todayand tomorrow , and residents in Huntly will get to have their say on Wednesdayat Stewarts Hall. A final public exhibition will be held on Thursdayat Kinellar Community Hall in Blackburn. Each exhibition will run from  noon to pm.Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity Michael Matheson said: “The Scottish Government has given a clear commitment to dual the A which will see delivery of around  miles of upgraded road between Inverness and Aberdeen, a huge task but one we are committed to delivering.“As part of that work, we are taking forward the design work for the  mile stretch of the route between east of Huntly and Aberdeen and now we are able to let people see the initial options we have developed for this challenging section of the A.“A number of options have been deselected at this stage as a result of existing topography, engineering complexity and environmental impact. This includes those near Bennachie and those through Inverurie on the existing A.”The removal of the plan to upgrade the A through the Bennachie Special Landscape Area has been welcomed by Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin.Last month, Ms Martin welcomed campaigners from the Save Bennachie group to meet with new Transport Secretary Michael Matheson to discuss their concerns.The group also previously met with then Economy Minister Keith Brown earlier this year to discuss their opposition to the plans.Ms Martin MSP said: “I am thrilled Transport Secretary Michael Matheson has confirmed the route passing Bennachie has now been dropped.“The Save Bennachie group have tirelessly campaigned and shown true passion and dedication for their cause.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Members of the Kemnay Academy Rock Challenge Team accept the donation from Lynn Murphy of Tesco"  Bags of Help cash for pupils viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"“I commend them all for a campaign which has been time-consuming and, those who were a part of it, for their commitment and determination.“They managed to achieve cross-party support and I know MSPs from all parties shared a collective admiration for them.“I would like to thank the Transport Minister and Transport Scotland for all their work to date and for taking the time to meet with myself, other MSPs and the Save Bennachie team to listen to their views. Their hard work has paid off.”North East MSP Mike Rumbles added: "I’m delighted that the Scottish Government has decided to remove possible routes for the A that would damage the natural environment around Bennachie."I have no idea why it has taken so long for the minister and Transport Scotland to make this commitment. The option to ert the dual carriageway south of Inverurie and over the foothills of Bennachie should never have been on the table in the first place.“I have met with the transport minister and local campaigners here in the Parliament on several occasions and I can categorically say that it is thanks to their tireless efforts that we are seeing this progress today.“I look forward to exploring the options that have now been put forward and I will be watching to ensure that no concessions are made that could damage our iconic landscape.”

title: charity ball raises more than 45 000
story: North-east residents and businesses joined forces at the weekend to raise thousands of pounds for a cancer support charity at its largest fundraising event of the year.A total of  guests raised more than £, at CLAN Cancer Supports Wanderlust Ball which was held at Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centreon Saturday, October .The fundraising event, which was hosted by television and radio host Grant Stott for the second successive year, saw people from across the north-east come together in support of the charity. Guests were treated to a culinary trip around the world paired with Chinese Lion Dancers and Caribbean Steel Drums, followed by live entertainment and dancing.During the event, guests heard from one of CLANs clients who shared how CLAN had supported both him and his family through its specialist Children and Families Service. He was followed, on stage, by Polly Booth, Children and Families Support Worker, who described her work with the family, and other families like them in the North east.All money raised will go towards CLAN’s provision of free support services to anyone affected by a cancer diagnosis across the north-east of Scotland, Moray, Orkney and Shetland.Fiona Fernie, head of income generation and business development for CLAN Cancer Support, said: “We are absolutely delighted that the Wanderlust Ball has been a big success. It was so wonderful to see everyone enjoying themselves, all in aid of a charity close to so many hearts in the communities we support. CLAN celebrates its th anniversary this year and the success of the evening and the totals raised show the impact we have on people’s lives.“I’m very thankful to everyone who supported the event and helped to raise such a fantastic total. All of our support services make a big dference to people going through challenging circumstances and every penny means so much to us all at CLAN.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The youngsters enjoyed taking part in the litter pick"  Strathburn pupils clean up Inverurie viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: strathburn pupils clean up inverurie
story: Pupils from Strathburn School took part in a community litter pick on Wednesday, October  as part ofthe Clean Up Scotland campaign.The P RS class headed over to the Garioch Sports Centre to collect rubbish that had been left on the ground.Teacher Suzanne Rydlawicz said: “We decided to do the litter pick as part of our class topic which is Responsibility in our Community, and some pupils had heard about the plastic pollution and wanted to help.“The children have been very surprised at the amount of things they have picked up and it is making them more aware about the things that they would throw away.”She added: “They have noticed that there is a lot of sharp materials like glass and cans lying around, and they were worried that animals or children could get hurt.”The rubbish collected will be sorted and recycledpossible.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Members of the Kemnay Academy Rock Challenge Team accept the donation from Lynn Murphy of Tesco"  Bags of Help cash for pupils viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: get your skates on at ice rink this december
story: Festive celebrations in Inverurie this year are set to be cooler than ever thanks to the addition of a Christmas ice rink.The beautul winter ice rink will arrive in town from Saturday, December , to add plenty of Christmas cheer.Sponsored by Barratt Homes and supported by We Are Inverurie, the ice rink will hold up to  skaters of all ages and abilities and is perfect for a family treat, a first date, or a great fun night out with friends.For those wishing to watch friends and family enjoying themselves, there will be a spectator area, adjacent to the rink with refreshments available.We Are Inverurie Bid Manager, Derek Ritchie, said: “We are absolutely thrilled to announce that the Inverurie Ice Rink will be in town until Sunday, December  for this year’s festive celebrations.“We are really looking forward to seeing everyone skating and enjoying themselves.”‘Discover Christmas - Inverurie’ will start on Saturday, November  with a Christmas parade, Lights Switch On, live bands and a spectacular evening firework display to end the day. Celebrations continue on Saturday, December  with a live performance by  school pupils performing the BIG Sing in front of the Town Hall, and the opening of the ice rink.This year’s Christmas Market will be in Station Road featuring a range of stalls offering crafts, produce and much more .Ice rink tickets will cost £ for all ages, and includes hire of skating boots or penguin skate aid for small children.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Insp Colin Taylor, Police Scotland David Fyffe Scottish Land  Estates Lorna Paterson - NFU Fiona Robertson - Forestry Enterprise Scotland Helen Hunter APHA Cllr Iris WalkerSupt Murray Main, Police Scotland Cllr Anne Stirling Richard Huxtable - RSABI Paul McGuile - APHA Jamie Smith - SEPA Jamie Urquhart - Dee  Don Fisheries PS Ross Watt - Ministry of Defence Police"  New partnership launched to tackle rural and remote crime in the North East viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: ne charity marks 30 years
story: A charity which supports adults with learning disabilities and additional support needs in Inverurie has kicked off a year of celebrations to mark its th anniversary.Aberdeen-headquartered Inspire started le as Partnership Housing in  then became Partnership before adopting its current name in .Service provision began in  when three people moved from Aberdeen’s Woodlands Hospital into their new home in the city’s Fonthill Terrace.Now more than  adults are supported thanks to a range of initiatives in Aberdeen City, Aberdeenshire, Moray and Angus.Locally, the charity supports  people at St James’s Court and operates Inspire Soaps, a day service where iniduals have the opportunity to make soaps, candles, arts and crafts.To mark the start of its th birthday celebrations, Inspire recently held a special birthday party for corporate supporters, long serving staff and local authority representatives in Inverurie. Also in attendance were people who benefit directly from the services offered, some of whom have been supported by the charity for more than  years.Commenting on the event, Inspire Chief Executive Linda Gray said: “We are delighted to reach this landmark anniversary which provides the ideal opportunity to reflect on the many things which have been achieved throughout the last three decades.“We have lots of plans to celebrate our th birthday with a whole year of fundraising and other events.“These will not only hail the success of existing initiatives but will also provide a springboard from which we can look to the future with exciting plans to grow our services even further in terms of range and geography.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The A dualling East of Huntly to Aberdeen options"  Bennachie saved from A dual plans viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: staff raise over 5k for charities
story: Staff at ANM Group, one of Scotland#s leading farming, food and finance businesses, have raised #, for two charities.The money was donated to Diabetes and Alzheimer Scotland charities, following a campaign involving a wide range of fundraising activities.Staff across all isions raised funds by organising and participating in monthly cake days, race nights and discos, themed clothing days, members’ open golf competition, Christmas card donations, and raffles.Money was also raised by Scott Naismith from the Thainstone Specialist Auctions isionwho ran the London Marathon.The funds rasied will be split evenly between the two charities.Grant Rogerson, Chief Executive at ANM Group, said: “I’m very proud of our staff at ANM for raising more than £, for two very worthy causes.“The group has a strong track record of supporting charitable organisations, and we look forward to continuing with our future fundraising efforts.”The group recently concluded its Facebook charity calendar competition aimed to raise funds for two charities Cash for Kids Aberdeen and the Royal Northern Countryside Initiative.The calendar features top agricultural photos submitted by members, customers and farming enthusiasts and will go on sale priced at £ from Thursday, November .A copy of the ANM Group  charity calendar can be pre-ordered by emailing marketing@anmgroup or by contacting the ANM Group Facebook page.The ANM Group is based at the Thainstone Centre near Inverurie.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..!
